In its combination with modern materials and techniques, it appears to be a preserved historical monument. A narrow staircase leads from the rostrum on the hillock towards the open space below. The open space is dominated by another of the artist's works, a long "water gully" supplied with water from a jar.

data.title: Art - Integers
data.introtext:
Artist: Jan Eirik Evjen (1994).Â 

The lower section of the sculpture has square openings where electric lights shine after dark. It is, therefore, experienced very differently in daylight and in the dark. In several of his later sculptures, Evjen worked with the contrast between such shell-like external forms, exploiting the space inside the sculpture to evoke surprising perceptions.

data.title: Art - Three Bronze Sculptures
data.introtext:
Artist: Stein RÃ¸nning (1999).

These sculptures, located at the municipal water treatment plant at Vikelvdalen, have no name, but the intention is to focus attention on the road, the water and the landscape. On an axis from the Vikelva (a river) and up to the large building, there is a large accurately shaped bronze cube. It marks the scope and importance of the plant for the whole municipality. Two smaller, approximately cube-shaped objects are placed on columns at the entrance to the plant. RÃ¸nning is known for his work at the Academy of Fine Arts in Oslo, and previously taught at the university in his native Trondheim. As a visual artist, his works are often characterized by minimalist expressions in different materials.

data.title: Art - Three Jars
data.introtext:
Artist: Geir Stormoen (2000).

These three colossal jars made of joined granite discs loom together on small grass plots along the driveway up to the Telenor Building at Tyholt. The jars are part of a larger artistic programme for the centre. The sculptures are made from cut granite in different colours: red-pink granite form Bohus/VÃ¥nga, white-grey granite from StÃ¸ren/Iddefjord and black syenite from Bergan.

data.title: Art - Stone Memorial to Anders Buen
data.introtext:
Artist: Alessandro Santi (1938).

Anders Buen (1864â1933) was a President of Stortinget (the Norwegian Parliament) and editor of the newspaper Ny Tid (New Era). He stopped the plans to build large tenement buildings in the city district around Lademoen Park and Buran. Santi made a portrait medallion for the stone memorial. He was born in Trondheim, but his father was an Italian immigrant. He was a stone mason at Nidaros Cathedral Restoration Workshop from 1910 to 1948.

data.title: Art - Monument to Knut Olai ThornÃ¦s
data.introtext:
Artist: Odd Hilt (1955).

Knut Olai ThornÃ¦s (1874â1945) came to Trondheim as a young typesetter, eventually becoming the editor of the newspaper Ny Tid (New Era). He was also for several years a member of the city council and the city executive board. He composed music and wrote workers' songs and choir works. On the back side on the sculpture, a young woman (one of the muses) sits with a musical instrument. The sculpture has also been called Frem mot vold og barbari (Forward against Violence and Barbarians), reflecting a line in the Norwegian Communist song Frem kamerater (Forward, Comrades!). The artist was a Communist, and his political commitment appears in many of his works. The sculpture was unveiled on 5 May 1955, the local Music and Song Day.

data.title: Art - The Billy Goat Gruff
data.introtext:
Artist: Arne Johan Vinje Gunnerud (1982).

The sculptor Gunnerud has often allowed himself to be inspired by mythology and folktales, as in this case. He is well represented in most of Norway, but this is his only sculpture in Trondheim.

data.title: Art - The Boy who is Looking to the Future
data.introtext:
Artist: Elen Sofie Elster Christensen (1961).

Two years before the ship-owner Harry Borthen died, Gutten som ser fremover was placed in the street carrying the donor's name. Borthen, who was born in Trondheim, launched his shipping company in Oslo in 1917.

data.title: Art - Playful Bears
data.introtext:
Artist: Karl Johan Flaathe (1983).

These playing bears decorate the city districtâs green lung, Lademoen Park. The sculpture was donated by Gustav Aspelin Ltd. when the company celebrated its 25th anniversary.

data.title: Art - The Comb
data.introtext:
Artist: Jorun Kraft Mo (1993).

In 1992, a competition was held for an idea about how to decorate the roundabout east of Bakke Bridge. City planners wanted to add artistic works to the city picture, including its roadways. Mo won the competition with her sketch. Inspired by archaeological excavations in the medieval part of Trondheim, Kammen may be said to hint at ties to the first women who settled along the mouth of the Nidelven (a river).

data.title: Art - The Seven Stones
data.introtext:
Artist: Gerald W. Siler (1984).Â 

This abstract sculpture was made by American-born Gerald Siler, who is now settled at StÃ¸ren. The sculpture is placed in the grassy area between the buildings as part of the design of the open space. It consists of seven blocks of stone, four light-coloured (granite from StÃ¸ren) and three dark ones (larvikite). The artist often uses ancient ideas about the magical power of stone as the basis for his work. As the stones are placed here, they are slightly reminiscent of the giant stone monuments (megaliths) erected in the Younger Stone Age.

data.title: Art - Silent Water - Silent Land
data.introtext:
Artist: Jorun Kraft Mo (1994).

This decoration is an integral part of the entrance to the Statoil Research Centre. It is designed as an interplay between vegetation, stone, slabs and glass. The intention was to create a connection between indoor and outdoor elements, between architecture and nature.

data.title: Art - Fountain Lademoen
data.introtext:
Artist: Harald WÃ¥rvik (1996).

This abstract fountain sculpture, finished in 1991, did not find its place as a functioning fountain until 1996. It now decorates the street environment.

data.title: Art - Change
data.introtext:
Artist: Carl Nesjar (1997).

The sculpture consists of a steel construction in the shape of a twisted square. It rotates slowly in a pool and changes its character according to the seasons. It is an ice sculpture in winter, a water sculpture in summer. Laser lighting inside the construction reinforces the impression. Nesjar has been a pioneer in linking art with modern technology, and he has gained international recognition for his year-round fountains. The fountain was a gift to Trondheim from Statoil on the occasion of the cityâs millennium celebrations in 1997.

data.title: Art - Adrian Beggar Boy
data.introtext:
Artist: Astrid Dahlsveen (1997).

Adrian is a familiar character from a novel from Trondheim. As "a foundling, suckled by a tart and brought up by lecherous womenfolk", he is the main character in Kristian Kristiansen's novel of the same name (Adrian Posepilt) from 1950. This sculpture of him is situated in the garden beside Adrianstua (Adrian's house) in Ringvebukta, where Kristiansen lived from around 1955. Reidun Aune took the initiative to have the sculpture put in place. She also administered its funding.

data.title: Art - Equilibrium North
data.introtext:
Artist: Rolf Schaffner (2000).Â 

This six metre tall sculpture, which is situated on the highest point of Ladehammeren hill, is made from four stone blocks. It may appear to look like a gigantic bolt or nail driven into the ground. It is called Equilibrio (Equilibrium). The sculpture is one of five peace monuments that have been placed (or that will be placed) in Europe: In Mallorca (the artistâs home), Russia, Ireland and Germany (the artistâs country of origin). The sculptures are to be placed in such a way that the lines between them form a cross, each arm of which will point to its respective compass point. The idea is for the monuments to symbolize the wish for equilibrium and harmony in a world full of war and hostility.

data.title: Art - Hull
data.introtext:
Artist: Jorun Kraft Mo (2000).

This sculpture has become a meeting place for people visiting Solsiden (a shopping mall) at Nedre Elvehavn. This was previously the site of Trondhjems mekaniske verksted (Trondheim Mechanical Workshop â a shipbuilding company), where for many years keels were laid and hulls made. Hence, the sculpture may serve as a memorial of what once was. Mo was one of three artists asked to sketch a decoration of the open place by the main entrance to the shopping mall. In her work with the open space surrounding it, Mo worked together with landscape architect Christine Gjermo to place old machine parts from the ship-building days as decorations along the edge of the dock on the south side of the buildings.

data.title: Art - Memorial Plaque to Victoria Bachke
data.introtext:
Artist: Edith Meisel Aas (1964).

Victoria Bachke (1897â1963) was the founder of what is now Ringve Museum, Norway's national museum of music history, where she is buried. The burial site has a memorial plaque with a portrait relief.

data.title: Art - Two Cylindrical Sculptures
data.introtext:
Artist: Hilmar Fredriksen (1995).

In 1994, a competition was held for decoration of theÂ university college building. Fredriksen won with his non-figurative sculpture placed as aÂ lattice over the ventilation grid by the main entrance of the college section. The clear coloursÂ yellow, blue and green contrast with the rust-coloured iron underneath, giving a strong signalÂ effect. Fredriksen has undertaken varied artistic activities, ranging from the simple to theÂ dramatic, which often have a subtle message. The artist has had many public decorationÂ assignments and is a professor at the Academy of Fine Arts in Oslo.

data.title: Art - The Woman by the Water Pump
data.introtext:
Artist: Tone Thiis Schjetne (1996).

This sculpture originally stood in the entrance to the Trondheim District Court building. In the autumn of 1996, it was moved to its present location. The sculpture presents a woman collecting water from a pump. Female figures at work and in concentration are key elements in the motifs used by Thiis Schjetne.

data.title: Art - Cissi Klein
data.introtext:
Artist: Tone Ek & Tore BjÃ¸rn SkjÃ¸lsvik (1997).

The persecution of Norwegian Jews started in earnest in the autumn of 1942. Cissi, who was 13 years old at the time, was taken out of her class at Kalvskinnet School by the Norwegian police and sent to the Auschwitz concentration camp, where she died a year later. The girl waiting on the bench is a picture of an individual fate, but also a reminder of how the occupying forces treated Jews, as well as of the cruelty of war. The statue was unveiled on the 6th of October, 1997, the anniversary of the action against the Jews. Pupils from Kalvskinnet School participated in the unveiling. The school arranges a commemoration ceremony at the statue each year on the17th of May (Constitution Day in Norway). Tone Ek and Tore BjÃ¸rn SkjÃ¸lsvik, both painters and sculptors, made the sculpture together.

Â

data.title: Art - Decoration, TrÃ¸ndelag Theater
data.introtext:
Artist: SÃ¸ren Ubisch (1997).

SÃ¸ren Ubisch won a closed competition for artistic decoration of the faÃ§ades of the new theatre building in 1994. He considered it his task as an artist to elaborate on the symbolic value of the shape of the building. The rotunda around the theatre hall is a symbolic expression of the purpose of the building. It was crucial to work this into the decoration. In cooperation with the architect, the rotunda was furnished with stone covered in gold and platinum. Corresponding decoration was also carried out on two walls in the foyer. This artistic treatment may be called integrated art in the true sense of the term. The artwork that shrouds the body of the building is like a stage curtain dividing the world of theatre from the real world. The curtain is both part of the theatre and a symbol of it. The colours used by the artist, silver and gold, are also taken from the created world of the theatre.

After completing his education in Oslo, the ceramics artist Ubisch studied for five years in Japan, where he won a grant to study ancient Japanese ceramics. Ubisch was interested in the possibilities that the block of tile offered when it came to shaping granite patterns on large wall surfaces and did much work involving these. On his relief walls, he employs pattern repetitions that show the influence of minimalist art and the Japanese tradition without dÃ©cor.

data.title: Art - Peter Wessel Tordenskiold
data.introtext:
Artist: Johanne Kajanus (Sakonnsky) (1975).Â 

Tordenskiold, which portrays the maritime commander and hero of the same name from the Norwegian-Danish era), was designed in plaster by Johanne Kajanus (Sakonnsky) in 1952. In 1975, it was cast in bronze and placed in a fountain in the open yard of Ringve Museum. Johanne Kajanus also made sculptures for the Cathedral, but these perished in the fire in the Archbishop's Palace in 1983. Her sculpture Mor og barn (Mother and Child), which she made in gratitude to the doctor Christian Brodtkorb for saving her daughterâs life at birth, can still be seen at the E. C. Dahl's Foundation Building (for many years the maternity ward in Trondheim). The sculpture received a bronze medal at the World Exhibition in Paris in 1937.

data.title: Art - Olav Tryggvason
data.introtext:
Olav Tryggvason. Artist: Wilhelm Rasmusen1921.

There had long been a wish for a monument to the town's founder and King of Norway, Olav Tryggvason (approximately 968â1000). As early as in 1860, the sculptors Hans Michelsen and Ole Laulo were already in the picture, but only with the 900-year celebration of the town in 1897 did the idea come to fruition, and the assignment was given to Brynjulf Bergslien. The sculpture was placed in the north end of Ilevold Park. Unfortunately, it was made from perishable material that soon dissolved. The statue now standing in Torvet (the city market square) was made by the sculptor Wilhelm Rasmussen during the years 1917-1921. He was given the assignment after a brainstorming competition that many recognized artists participated in. He faced a challenging task. The broad city streets form axes that bisect in the market square, while Nidaros Cathedral stands prominently in the background at the south end of Munkegata (a street). The sculpture was designed and placed with great awareness of it as being part of a monumental urban venue based on neoclassical ideals. The grey granite column is 14.5 metres tall, and the statue itself measures 3.5 metres. It is the tallest monument in Trondheim and quite conspicuous in the urban landscape. Olav Tryggvason is looking north and down to the fjord. He holds out a communion vessel in his left hand and holds an unsheathed sword in his right. At the feet of the king lies the head of the Norse god Thor, symbolizing the kingâs victory over heathendom. With much pomp and ceremony, including citizensâ parades, singing and music, Rasmussen's monument was unveiled by King Haakon in connection with the opening of the railway line across the Dovre Mountains to Trondheim (Dovrebanen) in 1921. The column and the statue form the hand of a giant sundial made in a mosaic pattern in the city square for the millennium anniversary of Olav's death in 1930.

data.title: Art - Phoenix
data.introtext:
Artist:Â Lunde Johansen (approximately 1915).Â 

This casting from MÃ¸llers Metalvarefabrik (MÃ¸ller's Metal Foundry) is directly connected to the former Hotel Phoenix, later renamed Hotel Residence. In Egyptian mythology, the phoenix was a symbol of cyclical regeneration. It would incinerate itself and then rise reborn from the ashes. The sculpture represents a stylized bird in a fountain. It is most likely a copy of an imported product.

Â

data.title: Art - Mosaic
data.introtext:
Artist: Roar Wold (1970).Â 

Wold's mosaic on the external wall of the insurance company building in the city's market square, created in 1969, is made from various types of Norwegian shale with elements of Italian and Chinese marble. At the time, it was the largest external stone mosaic in Norway. Wold's earliest abstract paintings provide associations with geology, featuring titles such as Skifer (Shale) and Terra. In the mosaic, individual elements are broken into smaller facets, where vertical white fields are contrasted against a grey background. Careful use of yellow and green creates visual tension against the white. Wold was one of Trondheim's foremost exponents of abstract painting with a focus on formal issues. From 1961 he was a member of Gruppe 5, which consisted of artists with ties to the Department of Form and Colour Studies at NTH (the forerunner of the Norwegian University of Science and Technology). He also taught at the Academy of Fine Art in Trondheim for many years.Â 

Â

data.title: Art - Water Music
data.introtext:
Water Music. Artist: Fritz RÃ¸ed (1981).

This fountain sculpture displays fauns making music. There is another sculpture with the same motif at Blomstertorget (the Flower Square) in Bryne in southwest Norway, where the artist comes from. Fritz RÃ¸ed belongs to a generation of Norwegian sculptors who from the 1950s created a number of works in connection with the comprehensive housing construction project after the war. In line with the prevailing political sentiments of the time, these artists aimed to make sculptures that were first and foremost intended as "art for all".

data.title: Art - Young Mother with Child
data.introtext:
Artist: Wilhelm Rasmussen 1918.

Ila Park was established in 1891. In 1918, Jakob Digre, a factory owner, donated the funds for this sculpture, which now stands in an elegantly designed circular fountain in the middle of the park. Before 1983, the fountain was located in the east end of the park. Jacob Digre had strong ties to this section of the town through his company, Digre's Steam Saw and Planing Mill. The group in the fountain represents a woman with a child being sprayed with water by three seals. It is said that Rasmussen's wife served as the model for the woman. The fountain group is in a neutral classicist style, which Rasmussen developed and taught to the next generation of Norwegian sculptors. He worked in Trondheim from 1907 and received strong impulses from Gustav Vigeland, on whose recommendation he took over leadership of the sculpting work at Nidaros Cathedral. He left important traces in Trondheim, and as a teacher at the Academy of Fine Arts in Oslo (1921â1945) he greatly influenced the sculpting community in Norway

data.title: Art - Memorial Plaque to Johan Caspar von Cicignon
data.introtext:
Artist: Nic. SchiÃ¸ll 1935.Â 

The memorial plaque features a relief portrait of General Major Johan Caspar von Cicignon (1635â96). Born in Luxembourg, he was a famous fortress architect. In 1657, he became a Danish officer, and after the great city fire in 1681 he was given the assignment, together with Anthony Coucheron, to make a new city plan for Trondheim. Nic(olai) SchiÃ¸ll was Wilhelm Rasmussen's pupil. From 1927 to 1937, he was connected to Nidaros Cathedral, where he modelled nine statues for the west front.Â

data.title: Art - Carl Adolf Dahl
data.introtext:
Artist: Stinius Fredriksen 1930.

The statue of city engineer Carl Adolf Dahl (1828â1907) was originally placed close to the railway station, but was later moved to Fosenkaia (Fosen Pier). This placement is not accidental. As the first city engineer in Trondheim, Dahl came to have great importance for the technical development of the city. He provided the city with modern waterworks, built Gamle bybro (the old city bridge, also called "Lykkens portal" â Fortuneâs Gate) and the park areas in SmÃ¥bergan. But he is remembered for his work with the docks at BrattÃ¸ra. The monument was made by Stinius Fredriksen, who won a competition for the assignment. It was unveiled during the Olav anniversary in 1930.

data.title: Art - The Fish
data.introtext:
Artist:Â Nic. SchiÃ¸ll 1957.Â 

On the north corner of Tinghuset (the Court House), there is a memorial plaque to ten persons from TrÃ¸ndelag who were executed by the German occupation forces in 1942. The memorial plaque is placed above a cistern with three bronze water-spouting fish.

Â

data.title: Art - In Memory of the Liberation Movementâs Victims
data.introtext:
Artist:Â Kristofer Leirdal.Â 

The sculpture stands by a common grave for war victims. It is a symbolic presentation in which the war victims are represented by the son on his mother's lap. As to the one who is to continue the family, he also represents hope. Kristofer Leirdal brought artisan traditions with him from his home at Aure in NordmÃ¸re. He started as a stone mason at Nidaros Cathedral in 1941, and later worked there as a sculptor. His Cathedral sculptures typically show his understanding of the style of the Middle Ages, as in St. Michael, Den seirende Kristus (Christ Victorious), Billedhuggeren (The Sculptor) and Kongen (The King). Leirdal's works often have a simplified realistic style in accordance with the classicist tradition. He taught at Kunstskolen (the Art Academy) during the years 1946â52, and later taught modelling at the architectural department at NTH (later the Norwegian University of Science and Technology).

Â

data.title: Art - Judge Jacob Lindboe's Sepulchral Monument
data.introtext:
Artist: Gustav Vigeland 1902.

Jacob A. Lindboe (1843â1902) was a high-court lawyer in Trondheim. He served in Stortinget (the Norwegian Parliament) for Venstre (the Norwegian Liberal Party) for some time, later becoming a judge. The artist (Gustav Vigeland, who is famous for Vigeland Park in Oslo) worked on Nidaros Cathedral between 1897 and 1902, modelling cornice figures, gargoyles and Biblical figures for the chancel arch. As time passed, however, he became increasingly critical of creating art in the style of a bygone period. He had also been given the assignment of sketching a fountain to be placed at Ilevollen, a project that never came to fruition. He did, however, carry out a commissioned assignment of creating a burial sculpture or sepulchral monument for Judge Jacob Lindboe, which he designed as a fountain and in a style that we generally recognize as his. Five naked men pose encircling a cup-like stone urn. This urn is the only outdoor work by Vigeland in Trondheim. The National Museum of Decorative Arts and Design (Nordenfjeldske kunstindustrimuseum) has a replica of the urn.

data.title: Art - The Student in the Old City
data.introtext:
Artist:Â Nils Aas 1996.Â 

This sculpture stands on a plinth, which is designed to look like a pile of books. The sculpture reflects a classical tradition in its choice of the man-woman motif. It caused some discussion when it was first put in place, not least among feminists. The sculpture is based on the classical basic forms of the column and the circle. As a sculptor, Nils Aas moves between figurative and abstract forms. He also experiments with various materials, although wood is his favourite. His monumental sculptures and portrait busts are found across Norway, and he designed the Norwegian 10 and 20 kroner coins. Nils Aas had his great breakthrough in 1972 with his monument to King Haakon VII, which stands in 7th of June Square in Oslo. Trondheim Art Museum displays his bust of the Norwegian author Johan Falkberget, which was his debut work at the Autumn Exhibition in 1964.

Â

data.title: Art in public spaces
data.introtext: Art in public spaces in Trondheim.

data.title: Art in Moholt Churchyard, Memorial
data.introtext:
Artist: Lise Stang Lund 2008. Art consultant: Annika Borg.

The memorial at Moholt churchyard consists of three areas with urns. Artist Lise Stang Lund has provided each of these areas with a column. The columns are identical, 190 cm high and consist of two granite boulders with a narrow prism glass area between the boulders. The boulder foundation is inserted in the ground, and works as a frame around each of the areas with urns. The purpose of the glass is to connect the two tall elements of the column, and add immaterial qualities to the monument. The glass creates a narrow mirroring of the changing sky and surroundings. The pure and simple shapes have been chosen as an expression of tranquillity and equilibrium.

data.title: Art in Stavne Churchyard, Memorial
data.introtext:
Artist: Eva Kun 2008. Art consultant: Annika Borg.

Â 

The churchyard at Stavne has kept its characteristic features and time-worn atmosphere and is still a peaceful place off the beaten track, sheltered by spruce against busy traffic outside. In the angled corner of the churchyard, Eva Kun has designed a memorial consisting of semi-opaque glass surfaces that create a room in which to find peace, perhaps while sitting on one of the benches that are also part of the work of art. Even the sharpest sunlight is subdued here, with the space obtaining a golden hue from the evening sun or drops of rain falling like tears on the mourners. There are 96 nameplates mounted onto the transparent walls, which are divided into groups of three.

data.title: Art in Tilfredshet Churchyard, Memorial
data.introtext:
Artist: Oddvar I.N. Daren 2008. Art consultant: Annika Borg.

The memorial gardens in Tilfredshet Churchyard occupy the lower plateau, where the River Nidelva flows past a small wood. There are fewer trees to the south, and the view opens up to the river and the high skyline to the west. On this spot Oddvar Daren has created his work of art for the new area of urns. Three curved walls made from concrete form the contours, and give a house-like sense to the area. The area is an invitation to meditation, with its concentrated view towards an open sky and its incessantly running water. A similar gliding movement can be traced in the walls, with their slanting, glittering strips of gold leaf inserted into the concrete. Reflexes are created, shimmer and then fade all in the course of one day and are reminiscent of the eternal course of nature itself. Via a vertical opening in the south-east facing wall, a strip of light is let into the room, outlining long and short, and strong and diffused patterns, according to the time of day and year. On the exterior of each of the three wall constructions nameplates have been inserted, 30 on each wall, 90 in total. Each nameplate refers to one or more of the areas of urns. The slope towards the river has been cultivated as a park, and a path through this area leads to a plateau by the river, where a bench has been placed. This is a place where one can peacefully sit and watch the river and enjoy the surroundings.

Â 

Â

data.title: Art in Byneset Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Beret Aksnes: âJordblÃ¥ tavleâ;Â Jon Gundersen: âAtt o framâ;Â Johan Sager: âRikke 19/22/3â;Â Barbro Maria Tiller: âDet var en stille sommernattâ 2003/2004.Â Art consultant: Annika Borg.

In front of the entrance, Jon Gundersenâs sculpture welcomes visitors to Byneset Health and Welfare Centre. It has been roughly carved from stone, with shining polished surfaces, and looks like it has been collected from the realm of fables. With a head at both ends of the sculpture, it has the appearance of both entering and leaving the place. In this manner, the sculpture mirrors the constant activity in this part of the building. Another sculpture is by Beret Aksnes in the shape of a pure, simple, rectangular, high and free-standing textile form. âDet var en stille sommernattâ (âIt was a quiet summerâs nightâ) is the title of Barbro Maria Tillerâs contribution to the interior surroundings. These narrative keywords have been used on a picture frieze on the upper part of long wall of one of the main day rooms in the building. The visual narrative, displayed in the artistâs simple, child-like lines, consists of well-known elements such as a fox, spruce trees and houses. The figurative images, created by the Swedish artist Johan Sager, provide sharp lines on a white background.

Â

data.title: Art in Havsteinekra Health and Welfare Wentre
data.introtext:
Artists: Philipp Dommen: âHavsteinerâ;Â Erika Hauffen: âGrÃ¸nningen, du som vi alltid lengter tilbake tilâ;Â Sissel Stangenes 2007/2009.Â Art consultant: Anne-Tove Huse.

With his three large granite sculptures, Philipp Dommen has literally brought weighty art to the Havstein neighbourhood. The grey-white granite shines and glitters in the sun, and on the rough surface, with its traces of the sculpting process, varying patterns of shadowy images are visible. From close up, we discover another material is added to the top layer of the three sculptures. Elements made from Plexiglass have been adjusted and inserted to the stony âlandscapeâ that the artist has produced on the upper surface. Like in a birdâs eye view, we discover a rugged mountain landscape on the lowest stone, and glass lies like an ice cap on top of some of the mountain ridges. On the two other sculptures, the surface tops provide associations with water, waves and the ocean. The glass enhances the wavy movement of the carved and polished stone, and lies on the turbulent surface like foam on a breaking wave. The three stony objects light up in the darkness, making them even more striking. The many glass elements, glowing like light fixtures in the dark, form new visual impressions, on their own as well as in a shadowy interplay with the stone. In the entrance area of the nursing home, Erika Hauffen has created a distinctive transition between outdoors and indoors, using coloured windowpanes that form a whole image. Inside the building Sissel Stangenesâ contribution consists of a large wood relief placed on a corridor wall, where the theme can be seen as an image of the life of flowers, from swelling buds in the spring to the ready-to-burst seed capsule of autumn. Stangenes has also decorated several walls with graphics.

Â 

Â 

Â

data.title: Art in Ilsvika Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Ann LundstrÃ¸m: âHeisekranserieâ; Octavio Gil Villegas 2003/2004. Art consultant: Monika Wancke.

The public art scheme produced for Ilsvika Health and Welfare Centre consists of paintings by Finnish born artist Ann LundstrÃ¸m and her colleague Octavio Gil Villegas, of Mexican origin, both of whom have belonged to the visual art scene of Trondheim for many years. Three paintings by LundstrÃ¸m have been purchased, and Villegas has painted several pictures which have been mounted on the staircase wall.

data.title: Art in Kystad Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Per Lysgaard: âKaktusâ;Â Anne Helga Henning: âOppe i lufta, inne i skogen og nede ved vannetâ;Â Eli Hovdenak;Â Kiki Prydz Wilhelmsen 2004/2005.Â Art consultant: Brit Dyrnes.

The ceramic artist Per Lysgaard is known for his applied ceramics in his shop in RÃ¸ros. At Kystad, he has given his imagination free rein when creating several large free-standing, imaginative objects. The artist has freely and humorously conjured up organic forms such as plants and animals, as displayed by the south-facing 3 m high sculpture âKanin med tre Ã¸rerâ (âRabbit with three earsâ). Towards the west, three cactus-shaped sculptures stand in a row in the garden. Exterior public art made from ceramics is an uncommon sight in Norway, in contrast to countries such as Denmark. Lysgaard has nevertheless demonstrated that the material copes with the rough Norwegian climate. To endure the wear and tear of Norwegian weather conditions, he has applied several layers of slip and an outer layer of glaze to the stoneware. The playfulness of the outside area is repeated in Eli Hovdenakâs interior graphics. Over a number of years, Hovdenak has used simple means to create brilliant situational comedy that often has a thought-provoking inner action and meaning to it. Anne Helga Henningâs drawings also have a playful theme. In the vestibule, Kiki Prydz Wilhelmsen has given the Centre embroidered work with flowers in golden colours.

data.title: Art in Munkvoll Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Marit Akslen: U.T.; Ulla-Mari Brantenberg: âBlÃ¥tt lysâ; Morten Egstad: âBenkâ 2004. Art consultant: Axel Becker.

Glass and woodwork are essential materials for artistic expression at Munkvoll Health and Welfare Centre. Outside the main entrance, Morten Egstadâs enormous wooden bench is readily visible in the vestibule area, invitingly soft in its form and anatomically comfortable to boot. In the corridor/entrance area, Ulla-Mari Brantenbergâs east- and west-facing glass walls are equally visible from the interior and exterior of the building. Several of the high glass surfaces have beautiful flower themes, whereas other windows have single-coloured glass of a varied palette. In the vestibule, Marit Akslenâs partition contains strongly-coloured, round, crocheted patches, united in a regular pattern with steel wire.

Â 

Â 

Â

data.title: Art in Tempe Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Anne Berit Nedland: âBalansekunstâ (Torget) & âLÃ¸ypeâ;Â Merete Morgenstierne: âLÃ¸vetann med frÃ¸â & âKanne og blomsterpotteâ;Â Torhild Aukan: âBarn Iâ & âBarn IIâ;Â Helena Kive: U.T. 2002/2003. Art consultant: Leiken Vik.

In the spacious courtyard at Tempe, Anne Berit Nedlandâs bronze sculpture âBalansegangâ (âBalancing actâ) takes pride of place: three female figures with African features, each with an object attached to her head. On the adjacent outer wall, her sculptural public art work continues with three bronze reliefs, all with human and animal figures full of action and movement. A fourth work of art has been inserted in the wall just around the corner, in the direction of the inviting garden, where three bronze frogs sit croaking from their position on the stones, placed along the artificial stream that meanders through lush greenery to a quiet pond. The garden is huge and hides another artist, Merete Morgenstierne, who has exploited natureâs own lush materials in interaction with her sculptures. The realistic, painted metal sculpture âLÃ¸vetann med frÃ¸â (âDandelion with seed headâ), has been encircled by latticework, the latter serving as a climbing wall for living plants in the garden. Inside the building, the organic forms are repeated by Helena Kiveâs large black line drawings on white walls, depicting trees. Torhild Aukan uses children as a theme in her photo-based imprints in blue tone on plate.

Â 

T

data.title: Art in Tiller Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Olav Ringdal: âSolaâ (wall relief) & âThe tiger leapâ (painting); Jan-Erik Beck: âChandelierâ (canteen) & âTrapsâ (street) 2003. Art consultant: Leiken Vik.

At Tiller Health and Welfare Centre, Olav Ringdal has made a sun out of large yellow jigsaw pieces,Â placed on a wall in an open indoor landscape. The sun shines and spreads warmth and happinessÂ throughout the year and in all weathers. Situated on an opposite wall is another similar-sizedÂ jigsaw work of art. Through the latter, titled âTigersprangetâ (âThe tiger leapâ) the artist has endeavouredÂ to bring energy and exuberance, by using red with dynamic movements. Ringdalâs large,Â geometrical painting is striking and independent in its calmness and stability, and serves as aÂ contrast to âThe tiger leapâ.Â The other art in this nursing home is from Jan-Erik Beck, whose glass and metal sculpturesÂ are suspended from the canteen ceiling and adjoining area. The two chandelier-like objects are assembledÂ from mouth-blown glass balls and rolled steel plates. In the main corridor, the materials areÂ composed of bended and welded steel bars, clad in nylon/polyester.

data.title: Art in Valentinlyst Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists:Â Anita Abtahi;Â Brit Dyrnes og Arild Juul: âAlfhildsâ;Â Erlend Leirdal: âReiseâDrÃ¸mâMinneâ;Â Kari Elise Mobeck: âUngdomskildenâ;Â Merete Morgenstierne: âBestefars Româ;Â Eli Anne Tiller: â9 Kvadrater 2005â;Â Per Rune Vatne: âLekende treskulpturerâ;Â Vigdis Dagsdatter Ãien: âMetamarkâ 2005.Â Art consultants: Anne-Tove Huse & Urd Schjetne.

Valentinlyst Health and Welfare Centre offers an encounter with eight contemporary artists from the county. Outside the entrance hall, visitors are met by a turquoise metal sculpture, created by Vigdis Dagsdatter Ãien. The sculpture is playful in its form and may tempt children to slide on it when they come to visit. In the welcoming and intimate garden space to the rear, Kari Elise Mobeck has executed the large-scale work of art titled âUngdomskildenâ (âThe fountain of youthâ), located on a vertical, curving terrace wall. Four high glass concrete reliefs have been placed on the wall at regular intervals. The reliefs are a representation of the organic course of life from seed, via germ and bud to flower. Life-giving water flows from three points in the wall and to a stone-formation in the ground.

Erlend Leirdal is another artist who has three-dimensional art at the nursing home. He has provided three large and heavy exterior sculptures made from solid oak. The origin of the sculptures, titled âReiseâDrÃ¸mâMinneâ (âJourneyâDreamâMemoryâ), is a 350-year-old oak from ÃbenrÃ¥ in SÃ¸nderjylland, Denmark. After the tree died, Leirdal secured the 6 m long, 8 tonne trunk. The trunk was transported to Trondheim and split into three parts, each measuring 2 m. The parts were subsequently worked on until their current appearance was achieved. They now nestle in their separate atrium courtyards.

Inside the building are displayed a long picture-on-the-wall series as well as individual pictures, both of which have been created by ceramic artist Brit Dyrnes. The themes are romantic and idyllic, evocative of the die-cut pictures collected in childhood. This picture genre is also the starting point for the public art project âAlfhildsâ, a collaboration with photographer Arild Juul, and a particularly visible and striking feature of the entrance hall. A string of digital photographs have been joined and transferred onto either aluminium plates or glass, and adapted to their respective wall or window position.

The remaining indoor works of art have been allocated to various sections of the nursing home, behind open or more closed doors: Eli Anne Tillerâs paintings in the canteen, Anita Abtahiâs ceramic flower reliefs growing along the walls of the ward for patients with dementia, and Per Rune Vatneâs small tableaux containing wooden sticks that provide associations with the fictional character Knerten, a wooden twig and imaginary friend to a small child, depicted in several childrenâs stories by author Anne-Cath. Vestly.

data.title: Art in Ãya Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artists: Elisabeth Engen; Karin Aurora Lindell: Glass decoration/design; Vidar Koksvik: âChandelierâ; Ole Martin Lund BÃ¸: âDoxa; âTrude Westby Nordmark: âCandyâ og âTransâ; Rintala Eggertsson Architects: âEdgeâ; Lars Paalgard & Per Jonas LindstrÃ¶m: âStringplayâ 2008/2009. Art consultants: Grethe Fredriksen & Astrid Findreng.

The public art project at Ãya Community Hospital is extensive and costly. The building towers in the landscape, literally and artistically. The works cover most of the six floors of the building, and most of the works are available to the general public. In the entrance area, the Finnish artist and architect Sami Rintala and his colleague Dagur Eggertsson has provided the building with curved railings, one part painted and the other made from rusty steel plates. In the canteen and library, Lars Paalgard and Per Jonas LindstrÃ¶m have jointly contributed to the atmosphere and character of the room, as their highly ambitious and original audio-visual work âStrengelekâ spans over two floors. Attached to a grand piano suspended above the floor of the library, a range of strings or wires that may be played on have been stretched out, extending from the library ceiling down to the canteen area. Playing the strings occurs at the ceiling level, and viewers have to crane their necks in order to view the installations and objects that pass along the strings and wires. In the auditoriums on the ground floor, Ole Martin Lund BÃ¸ has made his characteristic mark, with fragments created from signs and figures on the side walls.

Moving upwards in the building, the glass artist Vidar Koksvikâs chandeliers in the stairwell are striking and eye-catching. These functional works of art unfurl as soft, bent flower stems, shining flowers, and long, slender leaves. Each chandelier has one predominant colour with a hint of green and blue in the transparent glass. The west-facing corridor on the first floor has a considerable collection of glass art of an entirely different character. On the partition leading to the offices and meeting rooms, Karin Aurora Lindell has made her visual mark on many of the windows. Each window has received an identical fine grid, but in varying colours, that are enhanced and altered by the changing light. On the ground floor and second floor, ceramic artist Trude Westby Nordmark has an original application of her material. She has designed two suites of furniture, one inside and one outside, on the terrace where the view towards city is attractive. Outdoors, the suite of furniture is illuminated from below and âhoversâ in the dark on a blue âpillowâ of light, and is thus transformed into a sculpture. On each of the three uppermost floors, in two wards, an artist in wood, Elisabeth Engen, has decorated three columns in the day rooms. One column has a combined pattern of wooden stakes and other pieces of wood, the second has carved panels, and the third has plugs attached to it. Each column corresponds to a circular work of art hanging on the end wall of an adjoining corridor; the technique and colours in the corridor works of art â a combination of painting and natural woodwork â are recognisable from the columns.

Â 

Â 

Â

data.title: Art in Nypantunet Health and Welfare Centre
data.introtext:
Artist: Carl Nesjar. The Rose.

The Nypantunet Assisted-Living Centre was opened in 1992. ThisÂ abstract sculpture sparkles gemlike in the open space between the buildings. It is designed soÂ that it can serve as a fountain. Several small spotlights installed inside the sculpture have aÂ captivating effect on the viewer in the dark.

Life-Long Love

Artist: Steinar Garberg (1994).

Mann og kvinne (Man and Woman) is another name of this group of sculptures in bronze, which may be interpreted as a symbol of endurance and fidelity.

Â

data.title: Wall Relief
data.introtext:
Artist: Harald WÃ¥rvik (1989â90).

This wall relief, which stretches over three floors, alternates between cut and polished stone, and features shading in yellow and auburn. WÃ¥rvik prefers working in large formats.

data.title: Art in Laugsand Health and welfare centre
data.introtext:
Artist: Harald Samuelsen (1929â1981).

This statue was originally placed in a niche on the wall on the corner of what was previously Ladejarlen Pharmacy on Innherredsveien (a street). When the pharmacy moved into new premises at Valentinlyst in 1981, the statue was moved there as well. In 2012 the statue was moved to the garden at Laugsand Health and welfare centre.

From 1912, Samuelsen was employed as a sculptor at the Nidaros Cathedral Restoration Workshop. From 1919, he also taught modelling at NTH.

data.title: Girl with Jar
data.introtext:
Artist: Karl Johan Flaathe (1967).Â 

The sculpture was originally planned as part of a group with Refleksjon (Reflection) at Sverresborg School.Â

data.title: Art at Blussuvoll School
data.introtext:
Artists: Leiken Vik: âRenningâ,Â Samir Mâkadmi: âSonic Onyxâ, Vegar Moen: âDet blir varmere og grÃ¸nnereâ, Johan Urban Bergqvist: âBÃ¥de Ã²gâ 2007. Art consultants:Â Beret Aksnes & Anne Helga Henning.

The round red installation, created by Samir Mâkadmi, is a striking sight in the outdoor premises of Blussuvoll secondary school. The installation is an interactive light and sound construction, with archways that provide a feeling of space. When Bluetooth messages are sent from mobile phones, the messages transform into sound compositions produced by loudspeakers that are attached to the sculpture (for more information, see www.soniconyx.org). In the spacious foyer, Leiken Vik has painted a dense pattern consisting of vertical lines from ceiling to floor, in which the paint â in harmonised colours â has been allowed to run down the wall in a controlled process. For other walls, Vegar Moen has provided large and rich colour photos. On a large stairway, Johan Urban Bergqvist has produced a spectacular theatrical solution that fits in with the schoolâs long tradition of education in the dramatic arts and drama productions. With a dash of self-irony, a teacher might easily be amused by the sight of a skeleton falling from the staff room balcony in a frantic leap to the crystal chandelier that has been suspended from the ceiling above the staircase. A stuffed owl has been placed on the balcony as a marker of the wisdom to be found behind the staff room door. Bergqvistâs works of art also include a chess pattern on the staircase leading up to the second floor. The title of the work has been written in capital letters on the steps: âBÃ¥de ogâ (âMixed blessingâ, more literally translated as âBoth andâ). On the steps one can also read the message âSe opp!â (âWatch out!â or âLook up!â).

data.title: Art at ByÃ¥sen School
data.introtext:
Artists: Eirik Gjedrem, Annette & Caroline Kierulf, Solfrid Olette Mortensen, Peter Sutton 2007/2008. Art consultants: Anne Kvam & Anne Brit Krag.

For many years, the sculpture âSykkelpikenâ (âGirl with bikeâ) by Fritz RÃ¸ed graced ByÃ¥sen Schoolâs main entrance gate. The sculpture was later moved to the playground, and now guards the entrance to the assembly hall. The school area comprises buildings as well as a sizeable and varied landscape, where, the design of the school terrain has served as an extension of art and architecture â or the other way around. In this school, art is often integrated and has a function, not least in the pond on the south side, where Eirik Gjedrem has placed stepping stones in the shallow water. The 17 stones, each 20â50 cm in size and 10 cm thick, are made from stoneware produced by Tommerup ceramic workshop on the island of Fyn in Denmark. In addition to their physical purpose, which can provide both fun and inspiration to the users, the stepping stones are visually pleasing due to their variety of colours.


Eirik Gjedrem is responsible for several free-standing, colourful sculptures placed on footpaths in the school area, as well as a portal. The sculptures have an organic shape, inspired by mushrooms, and have been made from coloured Erik Gjedrem Peter Sutton 80 Skoler | Schools 81 glass-concrete. All of the sculptures have shining âeyesâ, made from moulded glass inserted into round holes in the surface. In cooperation with the 650 pupils at ByÃ¥sen School, Gjedrem has also made another striking sculpture. Measuring 250 x 260 x 70 cm, this sculpture is the largest of them all, and just as colourful and original. Each pupil was permitted to shape his or her own small ceramic tile, associating freely around the theme âDrÃ¸mmebÃ¦rerâ (âDream bearerâ), the artistâs title for the work. The tiles were made from glazed stoneware, and were afterwards attached to the core of the sculpture, a polystyrene and concrete construction, using white filler. With its central location in school, âDrÃ¸mmebÃ¦rerâ is a daily reminder to the pupils that they have contributed to a significant piece of school art. In addition, the sculpture provides a comfortable seat, with its round and soft shapes. Another comfortable place to sit was designed by Solfrid Olette Mortensen, in the form of a broad stairway on the north exterior side of the school. The steps have been constructed as a set of concrete âbuilding blocksâ placed in a somewhat criss-cross pattern. The same artist has also provided the school with another place for recreation, an original, round metal pavilion, located between two of the school buildings.

In the indoor area, and prior to the addition of the above-mentioned works of art, Skule Waksvikâs popular bronze goose and pancake sculpture is now shiny from years of childrenâs hands touching it. The interior of the school has seen a lot of new art in connection with renovation work and new buildings, among them a large east-facing glass wall, with themes created by Peter Sutton, and graphics and paintings by the sisters Annette and Caroline Kierulf.

data.title: Art at Charlottenlund Lower Secondary School
data.introtext:
Artists: BjÃ¸rn Bjarre: âIâll Do Anything For Youâ; Hermann Isaksen: U.T.; Bo Krister WallstrÃ¶m & Ãivin Horvei: âMastertileâ 2005. Art consultants: Pia Skog & Per Henrik Svalastog.

BjÃ¸rn Bjarreâs humorous stencil graffiti âIâll Do Anything For Youâ at Charlottenlund lower secondary school has a simple line and clear expression. The artistâs use of 88 Skoler | Schools 89 humour and surrealism has been a characteristic feature of his drawings and sculptures. In his public art project at Charlottenlund, the text âI love/hate schoolâ can be read on 250 coffee mugs, together with an illustration of a heart and skull.

For a number of years Hermann Isaksen has consistently been keeping up the tradition of metal graphics in Trondheim. A large graphic work on a wall in the canteen consists of prints of considerable height, put together in a rhythmic series.

Bo Krister WallstrÃ¶m and Ãivin Horvei bring bright colours into the school with their joint work in tiles placed in two of the schoolâs sections, as well as comments relating to them in an adjoining room. The two main works are mosaics measuring 2 x 6 m, using 12,000 ceramic tiles of varying sizes. The mosaics create abstract figurations in a variety of colourful themes and nuances, thus mixing graffiti and traditional mosaics.

Charlotte

Artist: Nelly Hansen (1965).

The sculpture is named after Charlotte Voigt, the daughter of shipwright Michael Voigt. He established a shipyard. From 1858, he lived on the property, which was named after his daughter, who died at a young age. In spite of its simplicity, the sculpture has some powerful effects on the viewer. Hansen was faithful to the classic ideals and maintained a naturalistic style. Her works focus on depicting women and children, although she also made some animal sculptures. She was born in Trondheim, where she started her art training, but she continued her career in Paris and Oslo.

data.title: Art at DalgÃ¥rd School
data.introtext:
Artist: Erika Hauffen 2005. Art consultant: Annika Borg.

As her contribution for DalgÃ¥rd School, Erika Hauffen has selected the well-known and much-loved literary universe of Selma LagerlÃ¶fâs âThe Wonderful Adventures of Nilsâ, which can be found in the school amphitheatre. The artistic solution is a concrete one, where a wall is covered by a large photo, providing a birdâs-eye view of a landscape. In front of the photo, up under the ceiling, one can find a hanging installation of geese. The picture on the wall is in black-and-white, which, with its soft tones, renders an almost fairytale-like impression â a result of the artistâs characteristic use of a primitive photo technique, namely a pinhole camera.

Nusse on a rocking horse

Artist: Astrid Dahlsveen (1981).

Dahlsveen works in a slightly simplified naturalistic form, often with groups featuring children and young people. She was born at Strinda in Trondheim and still lives in TrÃ¸ndelag. Dahlsveen was educated at the academies of art in Oslo and the Netherlands. Her production is not comprehensive, but her compositions have well-designed proportions and a lovely interplay of rhythms.

data.title: Art at HÃ¥rstad School
data.introtext:
Artist: Yngve Zakarias 2006. Art consultant : Jostein Kirkerud.

Yngve Zakarias has made his mark as a graphic artist, with his direct impressions of nature. First and foremost, it is the nature of the tree, the pattern of the cut and the growth rings which he has transferred onto paper. Thus, with the use of new material and a new context, he has created illusions of landscape, sky and space, length and depth in the surface. This direct approach is also present in his art contribution to HÃ¥rstad School. The work shares many similarities with the artistâs graphic pictures, though in a large format where paper has been replaced by an entire outdoor wall

data.title: Art at Ila School
data.introtext:
Artists: Torhild Aukan: âUnderveisâ og âVeivalgâ;Â Jan Eirik Evjen: âEt pust i sivetâ;Â HÃ¥kon GullvÃ¥g: âSkoeneâ;Â He Marli: âJujuvâ;Â Merete Morgenstierne: âVindu 1, 2, 3 og 4â 2005.Â Art consultants:Â Yngve Lintoft & Annika Borg.

Jan Eirik Evjenâs tall, slim sculpture in the playground of Ila School functions as a sundial, consisting of two stretching elements. However, it is not only the rhythms of the sun and the day that are indicated on the ground: once each year, at the summer solstice, the shadow edge aligns with an exact spot that the artist has marked on the tarmac. The sculpture alludes to ancient cultures, religious concepts and spatial movements, and offers the school ample educational opportunities. Raising oneâs eyes towards the sky is one of the traditions at Ila School, where the tower of the main building was built and furnished as an astronomical observatory.

School history and tradition are also the themes of HÃ¥kon GullvÃ¥gâs contribution to the public art project. On one flight of stairs he has mounted a series of paintings depicting old shoes, inspired by a shoe collection that was owned by the school and was formerly used to provide shoes to poor children whose families could not provide them with sufficient footwear.

On two of the three staircases, Merete Morgenstierne has placed a number of small sculptures in four wall niches, whilst the third staircase has a series of photo-based pictures, provided by Torhild Aukan. The fifth artist in this extensive contribution to public art is He Marli, whose poetic pictures appear in the library, placed low on the wall, and offer the viewer associations with dreams and imagination.

Â

data.title: Art in Markaplassen School
data.introtext:
'BlÃ¥ strek II'. Artist: Oddvar I.N. Daren 2003/2009.Â Art consultant: Anne Tove Huse.

The iron construction âBlÃ¥ strekâ (âBlue lineâ) moves in a variety of angles and heights, and may resemble a difficult geometry task, as it stands with its problematic shape just outside the classroom windows at Markaplassen School. The sculpture created problems of another nature to begin with, as the pupils not only looked at this work of art, but also used it to climb and sit on. The school and the artist thus had to communicate the purpose of this art project before the blue work of art was accepted and respected by the pupils. As a safety precaution, the sculpture was later reinforced, and in its new version it was renamed âBlÃ¥ strek IIâ.

data.title: Art at Nardo School
data.introtext:
Artists: Nahoko Kudo: âMellom jord og himmelâ/âBetween Earth and Skyâ ;Â Are Mykkelbost: Vindusutsmykking og collager;Â Gunnar H. Gundersen: âTermisk fonteneprosjektâ 2009.Â Art consultants: Helga BÃ¸e, Edvine Larsen & Marit FlÃ¥tter.

The new Nardo School has three separate, striking works of art. Nahoko Kudo was one of two artists invited to a competition on the decoration of the assembly hall and its adjoining areas. Kudo chose to connect two sculptures to an axis right across the assembly hall, placing a yellow âplanet Earthâ on the tarmac just outside the glass wall, and hanging a corresponding yellow âVoyager satelliteâ in the stairwell at the opposite end of the hall. There is clear visibility from one work of art to the other,and the connection between them is obvious to anyone there. The satellite emphasises the schoolâs technological profile. With âaerialsâ and other equipment, the construction comprises two whole floors from its orbit right under the ceiling above the staircase. Are Mykkelbost also moves between the outdoor and indoor areas with his foil patterns and Japanese âcartoon eyesâ displayed on the windows of a substantial part of the building. The colourful, regular lines of the patterns are reminiscent of sound waves or ripples on water, and can thus be tied in with technology and the natural sciences. Old schoolbooks have been the point of departure for Mykklebostâs large collages, which can be found in several corridor and cloakroom areas. Pictures and drawings from books have been scanned and assembled to make new pictures, figures, narratives, and connections. In one of the collages the assembled pictures make up an entire orchestra, in another they create a science fiction-like atmosphere, whilst a third collage made from various plants is more organic. Gunnar H. Gundersenâs work consists of an almost 30 m long bench and fountain in the playground. The end of the red aluminium bench barely reaches the fountain, and regulates the quantity of water and the height of the jet via the temperature-based movements of the metal. In addition to the outdoor temperature, body heat also influences and extends the bench, so that when the pupils sit on it they influence the height of the fountain water, and thus the work of art serves to demonstrate clearly how the laws of nature work.

NardoÂ

data.title: Art at Nyborg School
data.introtext:
Artists: Solrun Rones: âSong til gledaâ, âSong frÃ¥ hjarte til hjarteâ, âDer fuglar flygâ, âSeierâ ;Â Anne Helga Henning: âHva er det som gÃ¥r og gÃ¥r? 2005.Â Art consultant: Jan Eirik Evjen.

Solrun Rones selected the gymnasium as the venue for her art work at Nyborg School. With a series of nine paintings, all measuring 1 x 1 m, she has filled the 21 m long wall in the room. The wall is 8 m high, and the pictures are hanging halfway up the wall, so that they are well within reach of balls in PE lessons. However, the artist has had the frames specially constructed to endure rough treatment, and the canvases have been glued onto 4 mm thick, reinforced wooden boards. The quadratic shape of the pictures, the energetic brush strokes and varied use of colours all combine to create a rhythm that goes in all directions and thus becomes a dynamic element in a room characterised by speed and movement. The nine pictures are placed in groups of three along the long wall, using colours associated with spring, summer and winter, respectively.
In addition to the pictures in the gymnasium, Rones has painted an almost 3 m high picture, which is placed in the entrance hall, as well as an oval picture situated on the stairway between the school building and the rooms used for the after-school facilities.
In the outdoor area, Anne Helga Henning has made her mark with an installation created from steel objects. A pipe sticks out of the ground like a periscope from the inner Earth. From the pipe, sounds may be heard and on closer inspection the sounds turn out to be jokes, stories and songs produced by the pupils themselves, in combination with various sounds from the natural world. Next to the pipe, a âsnakeâ wriggles, making up a multitude of shapes. The head is turned towards the magnificent view, with a green light diode for its eye. On the back of the creature rests a blue, fictional animal with a lynx-like body shape.

Â

data.title: Art at Okstad School
data.introtext:
'den som leter finner'. Artist: Silje SagfjÃ¦ra 2008.Â Art consultant: Jostein Kirkerud.

Silje SagfjÃ¦ra is known for her graphic design and her division of picture surfaces into pure colour surfaces and sharp contrasts. These are characteristic traits which the artist used when decorating Okstad School, although the materials and techniques may differ from previous works. Above the glass doors of the main entrance she has filled a five-part window surface with a broad glass picture. The colour surfaces have straight lines and create fresh collisions between blue, yellow and turquoise shapes. A few surfaces of clear window glass help to create a lively rhythm and movement in the work of art.

Â 

Â

data.title: Art at Rosenborg School
data.introtext:
Artists: Heidi Wexelsen GoksÃ¸yr: âKaleidoskopâ, âHimmelromâ og âAirâ;Â Bo Bisgaard & Inghild Karlsen: âFantasier i româ 2010.Â Kunstneriske konsulenter/art consultants: Nina Gresvig & Edith Lundebrekke.

Bo Bisgaard and Inghild Karlsen have made a range of sculptures and large-scale paintings in the main hall at the new buildings of Rosenborg School. The two artists have intentionally created a work that is visible from the outside during the winter months when the daylight hours are short and darkness falls early. Their joint contribution can be found on all three floors and it has a vertical axis, consisting of photo-based paintings on the wall in the entrance area and on the staircase, in addition to hanging, shining sculptures on every floor. The paintings displayed in the entrance area have a huge format, almost 9 m wide. With their choice of colour and theme, the artists hoped to give an impression of lightness and optimism. The viewer may find associations with elements of the sky as well as nature both above and below water. The colours are youthful and âpop-inspiredâ. Such features also describe the 15 sculptures. The five largest are a little over a metre high and have been cast in plastic material with coloured pigments and illuminated by internal light fixtures. Thus, the sculptures turn into shining objects, which can be dimmed as required. The colour of the sculpture is an intense orange. Heidi Wexelsen GoksÃ¸yrâs pictures are also large-scale, and dress the arched walls of the various sections of the school. In each section there is a series of photos with a specific theme. One series consists of pictures depicting synchronised swimmers in different formations. In the other series there is no corresponding order and symmetry; rather, the eyes turn to the clouds that tower like huge white shapes against a blue sky.

data.title: Art at Sjetne School
data.introtext:
'Mose'. Artist: Inge Pedersen 2006. Art consultant: Ingun Myrstad.

The use of ceramics is more and more favoured in outdoor art projects. In Sjetne School this was demonstrated when Inge Pedersen made seats on a staircase located between the upper and lower levels on the west side of the school, an area where the sun warms the corner of the building in the afternoon. The work of art consists of 12 cubes with a ceramic surface, distributed on all levels of the broad and large 10-step stairway. The surface, including the top and four sides of each cube, has been meticulously decorated in intricate, painted lattice patterns. The ornaments fixed to each cube resemble the others, but none are identical. The colour has been varied carefully, using a range of nuances in yellow and green.

Â 

Â

data.title: Art at Strindheim School
data.introtext:
Artists: Annika Borg: âUnderfundig grÃ¸nn (forgreninger)â;Â Erik Joung: âPassasjeâ;Â Anne Kvam: âSpiralâ;Â BÃ¸rre Larsen: âGaffelgâ;Â Erlend Leirdal: U.T.; mfl. 2004/2005.Â Art consultant: Beret Aksnes.

BÃ¸rre Larsen is well-known for his sculptural sense of humour, which is present in abundance at Strindheim School. As the Norwegian name suggests, âGaffelgâ (âForkelkâ) is a combination of a fork and an elk. A hopeful yellowhammer peeps through the hole of a ring-binder and looks for the chaffinch. In addition, a plane has wedged itself into the construction like a highly unwelcome intruder in a birdcage. Anne Kvamâs colourful spiral, made from fabric, hangs airily above a high staircase. Annika Borgâs wall-work âUnderfundig grÃ¸nnâ consists of small and large picture surfaces assembled to form a more or less cross-shaped installation. Erik Joungâs picture formats are consistently small, but easily visible all the same, placed on the high wall on the stairs adjacent to the gymnasium. Joungâs pictures are metal plate figures, spread high and low on the white wall, and work as a whole composition and installation.

data.title: Art at Sverresborg School
data.introtext:
Artists: TorbjÃ¸rn SkÃ¥rild: âHalv tolvâ;Â Sandra Norrbin: âMoving thoughtsâ;Â Annika Borg & Per Formo: âDet Sverresformoborgske universâ 2007/2008.Â Art consultants: Leiken Vik & Siri Austeen.

The traditional school bell receives competition from TorbjÃ¸rn SkÃ¥rildâs original faces of clocks at Sverresborg lower secondary school. However, whereas the old clock was an absolute authority on time, SkÃ¥rildâs four clocks cannot agree among themselves on seconds and minutes. During midday break, the hands of the clocks display particular signs of disagreement. There is, however, nothing imprecise about Annika Borgâs and Per Formoâs joint indoor work of art. With geometrical precision, they have constructed a matrix, an intricate grid from which several works of art emerge. The point of departure for the matrix is a circle, divided into 30 degree sectors. Lines between different points in the circle create a dense pattern of lines, angles and surfaces. In addition, this joint art project comprises writings collected from old educational reading charts combined with words made up by the artists themselves. The purpose of the latter is to defamiliarise words â to dissolve the taught concept of language as a neutral medium for though. In general, the art project refers to scientific practice by constantly searching for order, connection and structure. The artists have used five different places in the building, and one painting is placed in front of the stage in the assembly hall, providing a visual centre of gravity. The colourful painting is titled âDet Sverresformoborgske universâ Parasolsystemâ, and with its geometric shapes it alludes to astronomy, science fiction, computer games, and colour theory. On a wall by the canteen, âMappamundiâ has been mounted. This work is a âmap of the worldâ. The circle depicts a red planet, where dense divisions have been marked in a blue universe. The third and fourth parts of this art project are the glossary and the collections of the art universe, entitled âGlossariumâ and âSamlingerâ, which naturally are found in the library. The collections can be divided into two parts: on the one hand there are columns of words depicted on a background of a geometrical grid, and on the other hand there are 12 books, each with 12 pages containing the artistsâ own âresearch materialâ derived from their project. The fifth and last part of the project has been given the title âGenariumâ, and consists of 52 colourful figures placed on a corridor wall behind the library. Each figure has been retrieved from the grid mentioned above, which forms a background on the wall.

Sandra Norrbinâs work provides a more simple expression, created directly on a wall, using three floors of the staircase by the âCâ entrance. Norrbinâs work of art consists of a painted violet line which moves upwards, curving horizontally as it moves along.

Â 

Â 

At the Source

Artist: Karl Johan Flaathe (1963).

The sculpture is also called Refleksjon (Reflection) and Knelende gutt (Kneeling boy). The artist donated it to the school where he worked as an arts and crafts teacher. The sculpture was planned as part of a larger project together with Piken med krukken (The Girl with the Jar), which now stands at Lade Rehabilitation Centre.

Flaathe, who was born in Trondheim, was employed as a stone mason at Nidaros Cathedral Restoration Workshop from 1945 to 1960. His sculptures often feature strict external shapes, which may give them a sense of being turned inward, but virtually unnoticeable level shifts and careful surface variations imbue the works with life. Flaathe did much work for TrÃ¸ndelag Bildende Kunstnere (Visual Artists), and also took part in launching the School of Fine Arts in Trondheim, where he taught from 1950 to 1975. He was open to new impulses, making a series of installation-like sculptures, which were radically different from his previous works.

data.title: Prinsen Cinema
data.introtext:
Trondheim Kino runs two multiplexes; Prinsen and Nova. Both offer a large and varied film program. The multiplexes are equipped with comfortable seating, first class image and superb sound quality (also 3D). Open every day except Christmas Eve and 17th of May. No voice dubbing on films, except child movies.

Contact Info:

Address: Prinsens gate 2B, Trondheim.

Phone: +4773808800

E-mail: Send an e-mail

Web: Visit website

data.title: Art at Ãsheim Secondary School
data.introtext:
Artists: Lars Fiske: âNy faneâ;Â Ole Martin Lund BÃ¸: âFragileâ;Â Mikal Christos Hafsahl: âMouse morning memoriesâ 2005.Â Art consultants: Jostein Kirkerud & Per Henrik Svalastog.

Ole Martin Lund BÃ¸âs work of art at Ãsheim lower secondary school is a reminder of young peopleâs need for safety and protection. The artist has inscribed the English word âfragileâ in the playground area. This simple word serves as a useful reminder both for the adults who are there to take care of the adolescents in the school and for the young people themselves, about their responsibility for their own lives as well as of others. Lars Fiskeâs contribution was a suggestion for a new logo for the school. The 3 x 2 m painted banner âNy faneâ (âNew bannerâ) has youthful speed and dynamics as well as a cartoon-like line. The third artist represented at the school is Mikal Christos Hafsahl from Studio Ludo in Stavanger, who has supplied a series of football-based pictures for use in several rooms. Alternating between themes from everyday life and cartoon-like mice, the pictures offer surprising impressions and variations.

Â

data.title: Art at Ãsvang School
data.introtext:
Artists: Annika Borg: âSpille-româ;Â Espen Gangvik: âAscending, Descending, Transcendingâ 2004/2005.Â Art consultant: Torhild Aukan.

Espen Gangvikâs contribution to the public art project at Ãsvang School is an outdoor steel sculpture mounted on a wall that is visible from both the playground and the road running past the school. As is often the case with Gangvik, his sculpture is a geometrical construction with right angles that makes it reminiscent of a staircase. The title âAscending, Descending, Transcendingâ supports this impression. In addition to up-and-down movement, the title also suggests a figurative meaning to mull over. The sculpture consists of two more or less identical elements. It has been painted in blue and mounted on a wall with a slight clearance, the resulting shadow-effect enhances the impression of three-dimensionality. Inside the building, Annika Borg has utilised a wall for her picture installation âSpille-româ, where the circular and quadratic shapes of the pictures, as well as their simple expression, are reminiscent of both balls and cubes, i.e. physical objects connected to playing.

Affluent Pig

Artist: Ãyvind Ãstein (1981).

This sculpture, made for the centennial of Ãsvang School, stands on "Grishaugen" (Pig Hill), which is just behind the school. Ãstein's style is to make clean figures with no unnecessary detail. Through the years he has worked much with animal motifs, preferably animals not often found in art. His sculptures are often satirical and critical of society. This sculptureâs title may refer to societyâs overconsumption of resources.

Â

data.title: Art at Ranheim school
data.introtext:
Artists: Oddvar Daren. Title: âRÃ¸dt tÃ¥rnâ 2011 Lars Skjelbreia. Title: âTreportalâ 2012 Martine Linge. Title: âTo tegnâ 2011 Kim HiorthÃ¸y, Erlend Loe . Title: âRanheims kosmologi/Ranheims encyklopedi/Tidskapselâ. Art consultants: Torhild Aukan, Markus Lantto

The new Ranheim Primary was built on a plot near the sea, where elevations in the natural terrain provide vast vistas of the fjord. Oddvar Daren, one of the veterans in Trondheimâs art circle, took advantage of this when he created his towering sculpture âRÃ¸dt tÃ¥rnâ (âRed Towerâ), which with its vertical design cuts a stark contrast to the horizontal lines of the landscape. The work consists of long, slender beams of ore-pine painted red and placed edgeways at different angles. Inside this jumble of diagonal lines, the artist has placed large, shiny silver coloured balls that give off mirror reflections of the red construction as well as the surroundings near and far, the sky and drifting clouds. Underneath the sculpture there are benches inviting the public to spend a moment in close proximity to the artwork. From here, it can be viewed in the context of the landscape that surrounds it, and perhaps even the thoughts of the beholder. This is a place to let the mind drift and daydream for a while.

Wood is a natural choice of material for an artwork in a place where timber and the Ranheim paper mill have played such an important part in local industry. Just like at the mill, Lars Skjelbreia destroys the rough log, but lets it keep its firmness, its strength and character in the sculpture âTreportalâ (âWooden portalâ). The log is now cut into thin slivers and hollowed out, but still in its original, long shape and with the irregular outline of the tree trunk. It is placed inside a protective rectangular box made from prepared wood, demonstrating a juxtaposition between the organic and the industrial. Its position in the schoolyard works well with the straight angles and architecture of the school building. Skjelbreia is one of the younger artists to join the established circle of artist at Lademoen Kunstnerverksteder. He studied at Iceland Academy of the Arts, Reykjavik (2003â06) and Trondheim Academy of Fine Art (2007â09). His artistic work has also been inspired by visits to the United States, and he has made his mark with a wide range of artistic styles, from film to sculpture.

A third sculptural piece at Ranheim Primary is âTo tegnâ (âTwo charactersâ) by Martine Linge. The 2 metres tall granite sculpture in two parts is sitting on top of a little hill in the schoolâs outdoor area. It is visible from afar, but invites people to look at it up close and interact with it. The stone has been sculpted into the letters âhâ and âÃ¦â, making an obvious reading of it as the local interjection âhÃ¦â (âhuhâ) (!), suggesting something surprising or unexpected, as well as signifying local identity and sense of belonging. The sculpture also offers a physical challenge, being perfectly suited for climbing on, before taking a rest on the top of it.
Â 
Indoors, Ranheim Primary houses a series of playful figures drawn by Kim HiorthÃ¸y, accompanied by thought provoking texts by Erlend Loe. The figures are made from brushed aluminium cut-outs with foil-transferred drawings.Â  HiorthÃ¸y studied at Trondheim Academy of Fine Art (1991â96), and has since been a prolific artist working across multiple disciplines, such as illustration, photography, writing and music. After periods of staying in Copenhagen, New York and Berlin, he has been based in Oslo. Erlend Loe has also been living in Oslo for many years, though he grew up in Trondheim. Books like âTatt av kvinnenâ, âNaiv. Super.â, âDopplerâ and the series about the character named Kurt, all of which were illustrated by Kim HiorthÃ¸y, have placed Loe as one of Norwayâs most popular authors.Â 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

Â 

Â 

Â

data.title: Art at Kattem school
data.introtext:
Siblings. Artist:Â Annasif DÃ¸hlen 1985

DÃ¸hlen mainly works with bronze, but she has also used other materials, including plastic. She is particularly known for her portraits, where she gives her figures a personal expression through her treatment of the material. She has made sibling groups for several cities in Norway.

data.title: Art at Stabbursmoen School
data.introtext:
Joy and Well-Being. Artist:Â Tore BjÃ¸rn SkjÃ¸lsvik

This statue of a boy is part of a fountain. SkjÃ¸lsvik's sculptures, which most often present animals or people, are very naturalistic in style. Unpolished surfaces help give character and life to his sculptures. The artist is a painter, graphic artist and sculptor.

data.title: Art at Nypvang school
data.introtext:
Cat. Artist: Astrid Dahlsveen

The cat, sitting on a natural rock, peers languidly at the sun.

Artist:Â Steinar Garberg

This sculpture is also calledÂ SkoleguttÂ (Schoolboy). It expresses a child's experience of its first day at school. The little boy is walking unfalteringly with his new schoolbag, comforted by his adult companion.

Â

data.title: Art at Ãsheim school
data.introtext:
Rhythmic Game

Artist: Astrid Dahlsveen (1983).

Â 

This sculpture depicts life in the schoolyard.

data.title: Art at Romolslia School
data.introtext:
Artist: Solveyg W. Schafferer (1984).

Schafferer's statues and groups of figures often show children playing and other day-to-day situations. Most of her works are in the naturalistic tradition, but with some simplification of the figures. They often have humorous features and the texture surface may be a bit rough. The sculpture is lively and presents children's interests and vivacity in an appealing way. Schafferer was born in Austria, but moved to Trondheim with her family in April of 1939. She later started at the Art School at Ãya in Trondheim, and made her debut as a graphic artist and sculptor in Trondhjems Art Association in 1950. She was later a student at the Academy of Fine Arts in Oslo under Per Palle Storm.Â

data.title: Art at Tiller Upper Secondary School
data.introtext:
Gemini I and IIÂ 

Artist: Espen Gangvik (2000).

These twin five metre high sculptures rise on each side of Tiller Upper Secondary School. The first causes one to think of the adventurers of old sailors navigating according to the constellations. It symbolizes the task of school: To stimulate the search for new knowledge. The second sculpture is placed behind the large school building, where its architectural nature plays in harmony with the body of the building. It provides associations with the vocational studies programmes. The artist characterizes the visible struts and frames as an "industrial and quasi-mechanical" expression. Both sculptures are made of aluminium. When natural oxidation has taken place, the tubes will be painted flat red to emphasize the main form.

data.title: Creative Hands
data.introtext:
Artist: Kristofer Leirdal (1974).

This sculpture was made for what was then Brundalen Vocational School. It aims to give symbolic expression to the content of the school, which involves creating through crafts and trades.

data.title: Art at Solbakken School
data.introtext:
The First Day of School

Artist: Petter Leth-Olsen (1977).

The sculpture is also called Mor og barn (Mother and Child), because it portrays a mother on her way to school with her son. It was a gift from the artist to Trondheim Municipal Authority on the opening of Solbakken School. Leth-Olsen grew up on the outskirts of Trondheim by Jonsvatnet (a lake). He was a businessman and a musician, who also painted and made sculptures in concrete.

data.title: Art at Steindal School
data.introtext:
School girl
